The purpose of this regional mechanism is to provide comprehensive support for HIV epidemic control at regional level in the republic of Uganda. Upto seven awards will be made to support and improve capacity of all district health teams and health facilities within each of the seven CDC supported regions to meet individual district / PEPFAR set targets. The DHTs will be supported to coordinate the Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.15: Biomedical Prevention - Medical Male Circumcision. Policy, training, outreach, message development, service delivery, quality assurance, and equipment and commodities related to male circumcision (MC). Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.8: Orphans and Vulnerable Children. Activities are aimed at improving the lives of orphans and other vulnerable children (OVC) affected by HIV/AIDS, and doing so in a measurable way. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.12: Laboratory Infrastructure. Development and strengthening of laboratory systems and facilities to support HIV/AIDSrelated activities including purchase of equipment and commodities and provision of quality assurance, staff training and other technical assistance. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.2: Sexual Prevention - Abstinence/Be Faithful. Activities (including training) to promote abstinence, fidelity, reducing multiple and concurrent partners, and related social and community norms that impact these behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.16: Biomedical Prevention - Prevention Among Injecting and Non-Injecting Drug Users. Activities including policy reform, training, message development, community mobilization and comprehensive approaches including medication assistance therapy to reduce injecting drug use. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

The purpose of this regional mechanism is to provide comprehensive support for HIV epidemic control at regional level in the republic of Uganda. Upto seven awards will be made to support and improve capacity of all district health teams and health facilities within each of the seven CDC supported regions to meet individual district / PEPFAR set targets. The DHTs will be supported to coordinate the delivery of accelerated and sustainable comprehensive, evidence based and of high quality HIV &AIDS services, identification of people living with HIV infection (PLHIV) who do not know their serological status, ensure that these are linked to care and treatment and virologically suppressed. Combination Prevention Interventions will be be key of work in "scale up" districts and link these to other mechanisms and other service areas like the miltary/prisons for transparency. This effort will be used to link communities to the existing health facility network, the Regional referral hospitals and the central MOH technical teams to integrate Uganda HIV programs within the Primary Health Care services. The partner will work with the DHTs/ Community Health Departments to develop responsive annual integrated micro-plans, five year strategic plans that are aligned to the MOH strategic and Investment plan, PEPFAR's overall goal and sustainability plan to transition HIV & AIDS service delivery into district and H/facilities systems, continously supervise, monitor and review performance in all supported districts.
